Award.AbstractNarration:
Inverse spectral geometry is the study of the extent to which the geometry of a
Riemannian manifold can be recovered from spectral data. For compact
Riemannian manifolds, the natural spectral data are the eigenvalues of the Laplacian. The principal investigator along with various research collaborators will address inverse spectral problems on symmetric and locally symmetric spaces and on line bundles over Riemann surfaces. They will also study the extent to which the spectrum of a compact K\"ahler manifold determines the structure of the associated generalized Jacobian varieties and Albanese tori.
For non-compact manifolds, the relevant spectral data are the scattering resonances and scattering phase. Gordon, and Webb, along with P. Perry, will continue their study of obstacles with the same scattering resonances and scattering phase.

Spectral geometry, which is rooted in spectroscopy, studies the relationship between the geometry of an object such as a vibrating drum and spectral data such as the characteristic frequencies of vibration. Spectral geometry draws from many areas of mathematics such as geometric analysis, representation theory, and number theory and is an active area of interplay between mathematics and physics. This project will focus primarily on geometric aspects, frequently in settings in which
Lie group representations play a central role. Symmetric spaces are the model
spaces of Riemannian geometry. One focus of the research will be the question of whether symmetric spaces are spectrally distinguishable from other geometry
objects. Other aspects of the research will be the relationship between the
spectral data and various geometric properties such as the lengths of closed geodesics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The research supported by this grant falls primarily in the area of inverse spectral geometry, where one is interested in the extent to which the geometry of a Riemannian manifold (i.e., spheres, tori and their higher dimensional analogues) can be recovered from the eigenvalues of its associated Laplace operator (i.e., its spectrum). Although inverse spectral geometry can be pursued for its own intrinsic mathematical beauty, it is worth noting that it has deep connections with spectroscopy and quantum mechanics, where one is concerned with the extent to which a system (e.g., the chemical composition of a star or the structure of a molecule) can be completely understood merely by observing its “natural frequencies” (e.g., spectrum or electromagnetic radiation). The relationship between spectral geometry and quantum mechanics is at the heart of many of the problems pursued in this project. 

Intellectual Merit: Bohr's correspondence principle states that classical mechanics should be the limit of quantum mechanics. Motivated in part by Bohr's vision, a major and long-standing conjecture in geometric analysis is that the length spectrum of a Riemannian manifold (i.e., the collection of lengths of smoothly closed geodesics) is encoded in its spectrum. The conjecture is known to be true for generic manifolds (i.e., sufficiently ``bumpy'' spaces), but this result does not apply to many of the standard model spaces in geometry and physics. In particular, it does not address the symmetric spaces of the compact type (e.g., spheres and compact Lie groups). Using wave-trace techniques, Sutton has verified this conjecture for compact irreducible symmetric spaces of splitting rank, a class of compact symmetric spaces that includes the compact simple Lie groups equipped with bi-invariant metrics. Sutton believes that it will be possible to extend the methods to demonstrate that this conjecture is, in fact, true for all symmetric spaces of the compact type. Additionally, Sutton believes this investigation will advance efforts to show that symmetric spaces of the compact type are uniquely determined by their spectra, which would solve another long-standing conjecture. Sutton’s investigation of wave-trace techniques has also allowed him to show that the moments of inertia of a spherical or symmetric molecule can be recovered from its rotational spectrum, which highlights the connection between inverse spectral geometry and spectroscopy.  Gordon and Webb have studied the relationship between the classical and quantum dynamics of a particle travelling in a magnetic field and Gordon along with Peter Perry addressed obstacles with the same scattering behavior.

Broader Impacts: In addition to disseminating work through papers and public lectures, the PI’s were involved with advising research at the graduate and undergraduate levels and participating in various outreach efforts. Gordon and Sutton each have doctoral students working under their direction. Sutton has supervised 2 undergraduate theses. Sutton has also been actively involved with Dartmouth’s E.E. Just Program, which seeks to increase the numbers of underrepresented minorities pursuing STEM. During the summers of 2012 and 2013, Sutton served as an instructor at Canada/USA Mathcamp, camp that introduces highly talented and motivated high school students to advanced topics in mathematics.  Gordon serves as faculty advisor to the Dartmouth student chapter of the Association for Women in Mathematics, which mentors and encourages women students to pursue careers in the mathematical sciences.   She has given numerous research lectures to undergraduate audiences and has organized conferences and Special Sessions on spectral geometry.
